title: Globalization, regionalization, urbanization: an analysis of the worldwide maritime network since the early 18th century
descriptions:
Here is a potential abstract for the grant proposal:

Title: Globalization, Regionalization, Urbanization: An Analysis of the Worldwide Maritime Network since the Early 18th Century

This project seeks to map the changing spatial pattern of the world economy from a maritime perspective across 300 years, from 1734 to the present day. Leveraging the rich data source of Lloyd's List register, we will employ a multidisciplinary approach to analyze the evolution of the global maritime network and its impact on urban and regional development. Our three primary goals are to: (1) map the spatial distribution of maritime flows using dynamic and interactive visualizations; (2) examine the topological and spatial structure of inter-port links using graph theory, social network analysis, and complex networks; and (3) study the co-evolution of maritime transport and urban/regional development, integrating global databases on urban population, trade flows, and socio-economic characteristics of nations and regions. By exploring the macroscopic measures of network evolution, including expansion, shrinkage, concentration, and polarization, we aim to provide a comprehensive understanding of the intricate relationships between maritime transport, urbanization, and regionalization. Ultimately, this project will contribute to a deeper understanding of the historical dynamics shaping the modern global economy and its spatial patterns.

Here is a potential abstract for the grant proposal:

Title: Globalization, Regionalization, Urbanization: An Analysis of the Worldwide Maritime Network since the Early 18th Century

This project seeks to map the changing spatial pattern of the world economy from a maritime perspective across 300 years, from 1734 to the present day. Leveraging the comprehensive Lloyd's List register, we will analyze the evolution of maritime flows, network structures, and their impact on urban and regional development. Our approach will employ cutting-edge methods from graph theory, social network analysis, and complex networks to examine the topological and spatial structure of the global network of inter-port links. We will generate dynamic and interactive visualizations using a geomatics visualization platform to illustrate the spatial distribution of maritime flows. Furthermore, we will investigate the co-evolution of maritime transport and urban/regional development, focusing on the evolution of port cities and hinterlands, as well as inter-connectivity between maritime and land-based transport networks. By integrating global databases on urban population, trade flows, and socio-economic characteristics of nations and regions, this project will provide a comprehensive understanding of the intricate relationships between maritime transport, urbanization, and globalization. The results will offer valuable insights into the historical development of the global economy and inform policy decisions shaping the future of maritime trade and urban development.

Title: Globalization, Regionalization, Urbanization: An Analysis of the Worldwide Maritime Network since the Early 18th Century

This project proposes a comprehensive analysis of the spatial pattern of the world economy from a maritime perspective, spanning nearly 300 years from 1734 to the present. Leveraging the Lloyd's List register, a rich and unique dataset, we aim to map the changing dynamics of maritime flows and their impact on urban and regional development. Our approach will employ a combination of graph theory, social network analysis, and complex networks to examine the topological and spatial structure of the global network of inter-port links. We will also investigate the co-evolution of maritime transport and urban/regional development, integrating global databases on urban population, trade flows, and socio-economic characteristics of nations and regions. The project's outcomes will include dynamic and interactive visualizations, a geomatics visualization platform, and a deeper understanding of the relationships between maritime networks, urbanization, and economic globalization. By shedding new light on the historical development of the global economy, this project will provide valuable insights for policymakers, urban planners, and scholars seeking to understand the complex dynamics of globalization and regionalization.
